NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Bangladesh ends on 30 June.  
 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by a team consisting of Rezaul K. Khan (Mission Leader) and M. Z. 
Hossain.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In its effort to sustain strong economic performance and reduce poverty, Bangladesh 
faces the challenge of maintaining sound macroeconomic management. Improved institutional 
capabilities  of  the  key  economic  agencies  is  a  prerequisite  for  a  stable  macroeconomic 
environment. At the request of the Government, an advisory technical assistance (ADTA) for 
Efficiency Enhancement of Fiscal Management II is included in the 2002 technical assistance 
(TA) program for Bangladesh. The ADTA Fact-Finding Mission, conducted in October 2002, 
reached an understanding with the Government on the ADTA goals, purpose, scope, terms of 
reference for consultants, cost and financing arrangements, and implementation arrangements.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is the key economic government agency. Its Finance 
Division (i) prepares and implements the national budget; (ii) manages and coordinates fiscal, 
monetary, and external sector policies; and (iii) designs and implements important economic 
and structural reforms.  
 
3.  ADB provided two TAs to strengthen the research and policy analysis capabilities of the 
Finance Division,2 which lacked the capacity to address structural reform in a comprehensive 
and analytical manner based on a clear understanding of macroeconomic implications. Policy 
changes  used  to  be  considered  in  an  ad  hoc  manner  without  assessment  of  the 
interrelationships between policy efforts and goals in dealing with long-term objectives and 
short-term situations.  
 
4.  Both TAs achieved their major objectives and the following: 
 
(i)  A  dynamic  computable  general  equilibrium  (CGE)  model  was  developed  to 
address  policy  issues  of  concern  to  the  Finance  Division.  Several  training 
courses  were  conducted  to  transfer  the  modeling  expertise  to  the  Finance 
Division, other government agencies, and research and academic institutions. As 
a result, several Finance Division staff are now capable of running the CGE 
model, which was applied for policy analyses, and monitoring of policy impact 
and evaluation of policy options. The Finance Division prepared a large number 
of  analytical  papers  on  different  national  and  international  economic  issues, 
which  helped  the  Government  address  several  policy  issues.  Several 
development workshops were also conducted to discuss the major fiscal and 
macroeconomic development issues.  
 
(ii)  Five studies were done on domestic debt management, nontax revenue and non-
National  Board  of  Revenue  (NBR)  taxes,  monitoring  system  of  state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs), public sector wages and salaries, and debt service liabilities 
of public organizations. Finance Division staff helped finalize these studies, which 
were then examined during workshops and used in training programs. These 
studies have enabled the Finance Division to conduct policy dialogue with other 
agencies. An action plan on the basis of the studies' recommendations was 
formulated for implementation.

2 
 
(iii)  Three officers from the Economic Adviser’s Wing (EAW) of the Finance Division 
were placed full-time under the Project, and the long-term national consultants 
imparted rigorous on-the-job training.3 The officers took over the responsibility to 
prepare  various  management  reports  developed  under  the  TAs  to  support 
institutional needs. A local area network (LAN) has been set up under the TA, 
connecting the Budget Wing, Development Wing, Nontax Cell, Monitoring Cell, 
Economic Adviser’s Wing, and the Project Office. 
 
(iv)  Various  weekly,  fortnightly,  and  monthly  management  reports  were 
institutionalized  in  MOF.4  The  TAs  helped  the  Finance  Division  prepare  the 
budget and post-budget economic reviews and in undertaking dialogue with the 
development partners, including the World Bank, International Monetary Fund 
(IMF), and ADB. 
 
5.  ADB-assisted initiatives have considerably enhanced the Finance Division's institutional 
capabilities. An operational framework has been developed to conduct research and analysis on 
structural reforms and policy changes based on a clear understanding of macroeconomic and 
sectoral  implications.  Still,  the  analytical  framework  cannot  be  fully  institutionalized  as  the 
Finance Division lacked adequate professional staff with requisite training in macroeconomics 
and fiscal policy analyses. The CGE model developed under the earlier TAs is now outdated, 
and ineffective in meeting the changing needs of the Finance Division to conduct simulations in 
monetary, fiscal, and external sector policies. The present FORTRAN-based solution program is 
not user-friendly and cannot meet the new requirements.5 The absence of proper organizational 
arrangements in the Finance Division also impedes internalization of the analytical framework. 
The Finance Division's institutional structure is not effective in coordinating the analytical needs 
of different functional wings and providing feedback, assimilating the analytical outputs and 
applying them as policy inputs, and identifying needs for updating and refining policy actions. 
Although a number of Finance Division officers now have access to computers, only a few are 
connected through LAN and have Internet facilities, which hampers coordination among officials 
and their operational efficiency.  
 
6.  The  Finance  Division  is  also  inefficient  in  several  other  areas  of  fiscal  and 
macroeconomic  management.  Remittances  from  overseas  workers  are  the  most  important 
source  of  external  resource  inflows,  after  earnings  from  merchandise  exports.  Because  of 
inefficiency in sending remittances through official channels, a sizable part is sent through 
unofficial routes. SOEs drain the national exchequer. The Finance Division lacks the capacity to 
assess the budgetary implications of performance and divestiture of SOEs. The SOE monitoring 
system needs improvement in several areas to generate more reliable and updated key SOE 
performance indicators, and to design and develop appropriate SOE performance contracting 
systems.   
 
7.  Considering that the issues are institutional, the Finance Division needs more support 
and assistance to sustain the accomplishments under the earlier TAs in fiscal management and 
to strengthen the division’s capacity in other important areas. Assistance is needed in updating 
modeling expertise, addressing institutional weaknesses in the analytical framework, developing

effective  institutional  arrangements  to  monitor  SOEs  and  improve  remittance  inflows,  and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The ADTA will enhance the Finance Division's ability to analyze fiscal, monetary, and 
external sector policies efficiently and effectively. The ADTA's purpose is to improve the quality 
and  timeliness  of  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  policy  analysis.  The  ADTA's  expected  major 
outputs  are  (i)  improved  institutional  arrangements  for  macroeconomic  and  fiscal  policy 
analyses, (ii) upgraded CGE modeling expertise, (iii) improved SOE monitoring systems, (iv) an 
efficient  system  for  remitting  overseas  workers’  earnings,  and  (v)  upgraded  professional 
expertise in macroeconomics and fiscal policy analysis. The ADTA will enable the Finance 
Division to better assess the benefits and costs of various policy reforms, mobilize domestic 
resources and overseas workers’ remittances, conduct policy dialogue with the development 
partners, and internalize an analytical framework. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The ADTA includes specialist assistance and other institutional support to enhance the 
Finance Division's analytical and research capabilities. The ADTA will accomplish the following: 
 
(i)  Analyze and address the Finance Division’s institutional weaknesses by (a) 
conducting an institutional analysis of the Finance Division, (b) preparing an 
action  plan  on  institutional  arrangements  for  macroeconomic  and  fiscal 
management, (c) helping implement the action plan, (d) providing analytical and 
technical  support  to  operate  a  permanent  policy  research  unit  (PRU)  in  the 
Finance Division, and (e) conducting in-house training for government officials. 
 
(ii)  Restructure and upgrade the CGE model by (a) making it more user-friendly 
and transferable, and (b) training officials of the Finance Division and other 
agencies to use the model. 
 
(iii)  Improve  the  SOE  monitoring  system  by  (a)  reviewing  and  improving  the 
system, (b) designing a computerized reporting system on SOEs' financial and 
economic  performance,  and  (c)  designing  and  developing  SOE  performance 
contracting systems. 
 
(iv)  Improve institutional arrangements in workers’ remittance inflows by (a) 
assessing policies, regulations, systems, and procedures relating to overseas 
remittances;  (b)  suggesting  measures,  including  the  use  of  information  and 
communications technology, to enhance institutional effectiveness and efficiency 
to augment remittance inflows; (c) diverting remittances from illegal to official 
channels;  and  (d)  identifying  other  areas  to  improve  inflows  of  workers’ 
remittances. 
 
(v)  Upgrade  professional  expertise  in  macroeconomics  and  fiscal  policy 
analyses  by  providing  a  customized  6-week  training  program  for  about  10

4 
Finance  Division  officials,  in  a  reputable  training  institute  in  the  region,  in 
macroeconomics, fiscal, monetary, and external sector policies.   
 
(vi)  Improve access to LAN and the Internet by (a) extending LAN through more 
workstations with accessories and (b) providing Internet access to key Finance 
Division officials. 
 
10.  The PRU will comprise qualified officers, nominated by the Finance Division secretary, 
from the budget, development, economic adviser’s, expenditure control, and implementation 
wings. The PRU will be supervised by the Finance Division secretary and will plan and conduct 
the division's substantive macroeconomic and policy analyses. The TA will provide the PRU with 
analytical and technical support.  The consultants will be fielded after the PRU is set up. The 
interface with other agencies, including Bangladesh Bank, Planning Commission, NBR, and 
Bangladesh  Institute  of  Development  Studies  will  be  strengthened.  ADTA  activities  will  be 
closely  coordinated  with  the  proposed  financial  management  reform  project  (FMRP)  to  be 
funded by the Department for International Development, UK, and the Government of the 
Netherlands.6 At the ADTA's final stage, all systems/techniques/know-how developed will be 
incorporated into the Finance Division through various training programs and workshops.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The  ADTA's  total  cost  is  estimated  at  $750,000  equivalent,  comprising  the  foreign 
exchange cost of $405,000 and local currency cost of $345,000 equivalent. ADB will provide 
$600,000 equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost of $405,000, and $195,000 
equivalent of the local currency cost. The ADTA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The Government will finance $150,000 equivalent to finance counterpart staff, 
office facilities, and other administrative costs. The Government assured the availability of 
counterpart services, facilities, and funds by the ADTA's expected commencement date. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The ADTA is expected to be implemented over 2 years commencing March 2003 and 
closing February 2005. The Executing Agency will be Finance Division. Overall supervision and 
guidance of the ADTA will be the responsibility of a steering committee headed by the Finance 
Division secretary and comprising representatives from Bangladesh Bank, Economic Relations 
Division, Planning Commission, and different Finance Division wings. The steering committee 
will meet every 6 months. A project implementation unit will be established in the Finance 
Division, staffed by qualified and experienced counterpart staff, to facilitate ADTA planning and 
implementation.  
 
13.  The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. Two long-term domestic consultants, 24 person-months each, will be recruited 
individually; 6 person-months of international and 7 person-months of domestic consultants from 
an  international  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged.  The  international  consulting  firm  will  be 
selected  in  accordance  with  simplified  technical  proposals.  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based

5 
selection method will be applied in selecting the international consulting firm. The consultants 
are expected to have extensive experience in macroeconomic and fiscal policy analysis or in 
other relevant areas. The outline terms of reference of consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
international  consulting  firm  will  also  develop  and  organize  a  customized  6-week  training 
program  for  about  10  officials,  in  a  reputable  training  institute  in  the  region;  and  procure 
computers,  server,  network  components  and  related  accessories,  Internet  facilities,  and 
customized software (according to ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement) to extend LAN and give 
Internet access to key officers of the Finance Division. Two long-term domestic consultants will 
commence  work  in  March  2003  while  international  consultants  and  associated  domestic 
consultants will be fielded from June 2003. Two long-term domestic consultants will submit 
inception,  midterm,  draft  final,  and  final  reports  within  1,  12,  20,  and  22  months  of  their 
appointment, respectively. The international consultants will be responsible for specific ADTA 
study reports. All the consultants' reports will be discussed at tripartite meetings. The equipment 
procured under the ADTA will be handed over to the Executing Agency upon completion.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the  Government  of  Bangladesh for  Efficiency  Enhancement  of  Fiscal  Management  II,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3       
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work  
 
1.  Further Improvement of the Computable General Equilibrium Model  
 
1.  An international consultant (2 person-months) assisted by a domestic consultant (2 
person-months) will upgrade the computable general equilibrium  (CGE) model and will have 
following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Review and examine the existing CGE model in relation to the theoretical basis, 
transferability, and effectiveness of analytical tasks. 
 
(ii)  Update and improve the model to reflect effects of changes of various public 
policies on income distribution, poverty, and growth; and to forecast changes of 
fiscal policies on the external sector; money/credit/ capital market; and the real 
sector. 
 
(iii)  Analyze  the  extent  and  implications  of  using  the  CGE  model  to  conduct/ 
institutionalize policy analyses. 
 
(iv)  Improve  the  theoretical  aspect  of  the  model  to  make  it  more  realistic,  and 
reprogram it to be more easily understandable and transferable. 
 
(v)  Produce a detailed manual describing, for example, how to incorporate policy 
changes into the model and how to interpret the outcome. 
 
(vi)  Probe  the  possibility  of  introducing  other  user-friendly  models  that  are 
successfully used for policy analysis in other countries. 
 
(vii)  Organize a workshop to discuss and disseminate the findings of the study and 
organize training sessions for the Finance Division and other agencies. 
 
2.  Monitoring the Performance of State-owned Enterprises 
 
2.  An international consultant (2 person-months) assisted by a domestic consultant (3 
person-months) will review the existing monitoring system of the performance of state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs) and will have the following responsibilities:  
 
(i)  Review the existing SOE monitoring system (system for autonomous bodies 
reporting  and  evaluation  [SABRE])  and  improve/update  it  for  changed 
circumstances. 
 
(ii)  Design  a  monthly/quarterly  computerized  reporting  system  on  financial/ 
economic performance of SOEs in line with the International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) format.

Appendix 3  11 
(iii)  Design  and  develop  appropriate  performance  contracting  systems  of  SOEs, 
linking incentives with a performance contract system in light of the experiences 
of other countries, such as the United Kingdom  (UK). 
 
(iv)  Implement the performance contracting system in six corporations/ enterprises 
on a pilot basis. 
 
(v)  Analyze the budgetary implications of SOE performance and divestiture. 
 
(vi)  Organize a workshop to discuss and disseminate the findings of the study and 
conduct one training course for Ministry of Finance staff. 
 
(vii)  Train Finance Division staff. 
 
3.  Institutional Improvement in Remittance Inflows 
 
3.  An international consultant (2 person-months) assisted by a domestic consultant (2 
person-months) will conduct the study on institutional improvement in remittance inflows and will 
have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Assess the existing institutional arrangement (policy and information technology 
[IT] environment) for remitting money by overseas workers and expatriates.  
 
(ii)  Examine legal transaction fees, time taken to complete a transfer, and tax rates 
levied  on  the  remittance;  and  assess  the  costs  and  benefits  of  repatriating 
workers’ remittance through illegal channels for comparison purposes. 
 
(iii)  Compare  the  IT  systems  and  policy  environment  with  similar  ones  in  other 
countries and identify the shortcomings of those in Bangladesh. 
 
(iv)  Study the IT system of the domestic banks, analyze cost-effectiveness of the 
systems,  and  suggest  ways  to  enhance  the  institutional  effectiveness  and 
efficiency of the banking system in augmenting remittance inflows. 
 
(v)  Suggest measures to increase export of manpower to different countries and 
ways to divert remittances from illegal to official channels and identify the areas 
that need improvement to promote greater inflows of remittances.  
 
(vi)  Survey a representative sample of remitters by district to help devise policy 
measures to enhance inflows of remittances. 
 
(vii)  Design a quarterly report system on remittances, comparative analyses, impacts, 
and projections.  
 
(viii)  Organize a workshop to discuss and disseminate the study findings.  
 
4.  Macroeconomic Analysis Specialist 1 
 
4.  A long-term individual domestic consultant will be engaged for 24 person-months to 
perform the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
(i)  Assess  (together  with  the  other  domestic  consultant)  the  institutional 
arrangements  of  the  Finance  Division  for  macroeconomic  and  fiscal 
management,  and  prepare  and  help  implement  an  action  plan  to  address 
institutional weaknesses. 
 
(ii)  Operationalize  the  policy  research  unit  (PRU)  with  analytical  and  technical 
support,  particularly  in  fiscal  policy,  and  domestic  and  external  debt 
management. 
 
(iii)  Develop and upgrade the medium-term macroeconomic framework. 
 
(iv)  Coordinate, assist, and comment on the studies on SOE monitoring, remittances, 
and CGE model updating and improvement. Suggest ways to control the quality 
of the studies.  
 
(v)  Conduct policy studies and prepare analytical papers on macroeconomic and 
fiscal policy analyses.  
 
(vi)  Organize development policy workshops to discuss the major macroeconomic 
and other policy issues of concern to policymakers. 
 
(vii)  Arrange, with the other national consultant, monthly in-house training for Finance 
Division officials. 
 
(viii)  Update  and  internalize  tools/techniques/management  systems  developed, 
including for nontax revenue, non-National Board of Revenue and domestic debt 
under earlier interventions. 
 
5.  Macroeconomic Analysis Specialist 2 
 
5.  A long-term individual domestic consultant will be engaged for 24 person-months to 
perform following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assess  (together  with  the  other  domestic  consultant)  the  institutional 
arrangements  of  the  Finance  Division  for  macroeconomic  and  fiscal 
management,  and  prepare  and  help  implement  an  action  plan  to  address 
institutional weaknesses. 
 
(ii)  Operationalize  the  PRU  with  analytical  and  technical  support,  particularly  in 
monetary and external sector policies.   
 
(iii)  Develop and upgrade the medium-term macroeconomic framework. 
 
(iv)  Coordinate, assist, and comment on the short-term studies on SOE monitoring, 
remittances,  and  CGE  model  updating  and  improvement.  Suggest  ways  to 
control the quality of the studies. 
 
(v)  Conduct policy studies and prepare analytical papers on macroeconomic and 
monetary and external sector policies.

Appendix 3  13 
(vi)  Organize development policy workshops to discuss the major macroeconomic 
and other policy issues of concern to policymakers. 
 
(vii)  Arrange, with the other national consultant, monthly in-house training for Finance 
Division officials. 
 
(viii)  Update  and  internalize  tools/techniques/management  systems  developed, 
including for financial condition monitoring for SOEs and public sector salary 
monitoring under earlier interventions. 
 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  The two long-term domestic consultants will commence work in March 2003 while the 
international consultants and associated domestic consultants will be fielded from June 2003. 
The consultants will submit the following reports: 
 
(i)  The long-term domestic consultants will submit inception, midterm, draft final, 
and final reports within 1, 12, 20 and 22 months of appointment, respectively. 
The  consultants  will  also  prepare  monthly  progress  reports  and  other  study 
reports according to an agreed-on timetable.  
 
(ii)  International  consultants  will  be  responsible  for  specific  advisory  technical 
assistance reports according to an agreed-on timetable.
